Fig. 1 Reaction performance of various catalysts. (A) Glucose conversion of the various catalysts, (B) EtOH selectivity of the various catalysts. Reaction condition: 0.5 g catalysts, 5 MPa H2, 205 ℃, 2.5 wt% Glucose aqueous solution, GHSV(H2) = 8400 cm3 gcat −1 h−1, LHSV (2.5 wt% Glu aqueous solution) = 12 cm3 gcat −1 h−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts. (A). the samples of the initial state (2nd hour); (B). the samples of steady state (15th hour). The Ru/CuWO4 (b) was the sample of the 40th hour. (a) CuWO4, (b) Ru/CuWO4, (c) Pt/CuWO4, and (d) Pd/CuWO4. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Raman spectra of the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts. (A). the samples of the initial state (2nd hour); (B). the samples of steady state (15th hour). The Ru/CuWO4 (b) was the sample of the 40th hour. (a) CuWO4, (b) Ru/CuWO4, (c) Pt/CuWO4, and (d) Pd/CuWO4. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 HR-TEM of CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts in the steady state (15th hour). (A) CuWO4; (B) Ru/CuWO4; (B) Pt/CuWO4; (D) Pd/CuWO4. The Ru/CuWO4 was the sample of the 40th hour. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts, (a) CuWO4, (b) Ru/CuWO4, (c) Pt/CuWO4, and (d) Pd/CuWO4. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Cu 2p XPS of CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 in the (A) initial (2nd hour) and (B) steady states (15th hour), (a) CuWO4, (b) Ru/CuWO4, (c) Pt/CuWO4, and (d) Pd/CuWO4. The steady Ru/CuWO4 (b) was the sample of the 40th hour. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Cu LMM AES of CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 in the (A) initial (2nd hour) and (B) steady states (15th hour), (a) CuWO4, (b) Ru/CuWO4, (c) Pt/CuWO4, and (d) Pd/CuWO4. The steady Ru/CuWO4 (b) was the sample of the 40th hour. Fig. 13 Efficient synthesis of ethanol and propanediol from glucose via a noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalyst Jiacheng Ji Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation a Honglin Zhuang Data curation a Ling Zhou Supervision Conceptualization ⁎ b Yi Zhang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ a a Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 China Department of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, China b Modern Agricultural Engineering Key Laboratory at Universities of Education Department of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, Tarim University, Alar, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region 843300, China Modern Agricultural Engineering Key Laboratory at Universities of Education Department of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, Tarim University Alar Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region 843300 China Modern Agricultural Engineering Key Laboratory at Universities of Education Department of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, Tarim University, Alar, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region 843300, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Biomass is the most promising carbon feedstock for producing chemicals and fuels as substitutes for fossil resources. In this work, hydrogenolysis of glucose to ethanol (EtOH) and 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) were carried out over multi-function noble metal promoted CuWO4 (0.1 wt% Ru, Pt and Pd) catalysts using a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Amazingly, the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst presented the best catalytic performance with 84.3% glucose conversion, 63.2% EtOH and 21.2% 1,3-PDO selectivities over 40 h reaction. An array of characterization techniques, including XPS, Cu LMM AES, in-situ CO-DRIFTS, NH3-TPD, Py-FTIR, and operando EG-DRIFTS, were applied to reveal the nature of converting glucose into EtOH and 1,3-PDO. It is discovered that the added small amount of Ru tuned the chemical states of W and Cu, resulting in forming the highest content of W5+ and Cu0 on the Ru-promoted catalyst, which improves the glucose hydrogenolysis to EtOH. Besides, the strong Brønsted acid sites (BASs) derived from W6+ contribute to relatively high 1,3-PDO selectivity on Pt/CuWO4 catalyst. Graphical Abstract Keywords Glucose Hydrogenolysis Ethanol Ruthenium CuWO4 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating energy demand and stricter emission legislation stimulate the exploitation of renewable and clean energy resources to replace traditional fossil resources. Especially, it is believed that to limit CO2 emissions, transportation fuels from biomass will be industrially utilized by 2030, and bioethanol will be widely used as a gasoline additive [1,2]. Therefore, efficiently converting biomass into ethanol and chemicals is a promising way to realize carbon peaking and carbon neutrality. Glucose, the cellulose monomer, is an ideal platform molecule for converting biomass resources. The good solubility of glucose in water enables continuous operation and a high concentration of feedstock in the reactor, which endows the process with much higher efficiency. Whereas, converting glucose into lower alcohols with a narrow product distribution in the complex reaction path remains a great challenge in the design of efficient catalysts [3,4]. On one hand, a great kind of possible by-products could be generated due to a series of reaction steps involved in the hydrogenolysis of glucose. On the other hand, the influence of solid acid catalysts with tunable acidity on the hydrogenolysis of glucose is still insufficient, which affects the establishment of efficient synergistic interactions between the acidic and hydrogenation active sites and leads to the unsatisfying selectivity of target product. In our previous investigations, the synergistic effect of hydrogenation active sites and the tunable acid sites was proved as the key to forming lower diols from glucose, namely, the lower diols yield was strongly depending on the competitive reactions of the glucose, where abundant W species and Ru metal sites on Ru-W/SiO2 catalysts effectively catalyze the selective cleavage of the C-C bonds in glucose and subsequent hydrogenation to lower diols [5,6]. Meanwhile, the special nanosheet structure of the catalyst established a balance of the hydrogenation active sites and acid sites via suitable reducibility, resulting in high selectivity of butanediol [7]. In a nutshell, the acid site plays an important role in the glucose hydrogenolysis reaction. Sn species were added as Lewis acidic sites (LAS) to convert cellulose to C3 products [8]. Besides, it has been found that the W6+ centers on the surface WOx species were proposed to be responsible for generating BAS, and the strong BAS should be the key part of glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-PDO [9,10]. Meanwhile, WOx species is considered the popular tunable solid acid site for the conversion of glucose and other biomass derivatives because of the flexible chemical states which make a great difference in acidity to tuning the product distribution. It is reported that W5+, acting as a LAS, can promote the cleavage of the C-C bond [5,11]. Besides, partial reduction of WOx could form catalytically active HxWO3-x sites to generate the BAS, which could stabilize electron density over several W-atoms without over-reduction [12]. Simultaneously, Cu0 displays a great ability to facilitate H2 dissociation [13,14]. Importantly, the activated hydrogen promotes glucose hydrogenolysis reaction to generate low carbon alcohol. Thus that, it is rational to create a catalytic system which possesses the synergistic effect between Cu and W species for selective hydrogenolysis of glucose to lower alcohols, such as EtOH and 1,3-PDO. Although tremendous effort has been made, an exhaustive active site picture for selective hydrogenolysis of glucose is still missing. Therefore, it is crucial to establish an appropriate catalytic system which gets rid of the interaction between the metal active sites and conventional acid sites to further investigate the synergistic effects between hydrogenation active sites and tunable acid sites for efficient conversion of glucose. In the present work, we discarded the acid sites with fixed acidity (Al2O3, zeolite, etc.) but synthesized Cu and W active sites via the in-situ reduction of CuWO4 to create hydrogenation active sites and tunable acid sites which are adjacent to each other, leading to establish the synergistic effects for promoting selective hydrogenolysis of glucose. Furthermore, small amount (0.1 wt%) of noble metal promoters (Pt, Pd, and Ru) was employed to adjust the surface chemical states in order to efficiently improve the target product (EtOH or 1,3-PDO) selectivity via a continuous-flow fixed bed reactor. The obtained catalysts were investigated by various characterization methods, including XPS, in-situ CO-DRIFTS, NH3-TPD, Py-FTIR, and operando EG-FTIR, to explore the synergistic effects of different active sits on the noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glucose (AR), CuCl2·2 H2O (AR), Na2WO4·2 H2O (AR), Diamminedinitritoplatinum solution (3.4 wt% in dilute ammonium hydroxide), Palladium nitrate solution (10 wt% in 10 wt% nitric acid), Ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate solution (1.5 wt% Ru in dilute nitric acid) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Co. Fructose (AR), Ethanol (AR), Ethylene glycol (AR), 1,2-Propylene Glycol (AR), 1,3-Propylene Glycol (AR), Glycerol (AR), 1,2-Butanediol (AR) and H2SO4 (AR) were purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Factory. 2.2 Synthesis of CuWO4 catalysts The CuWO4 precursor was prepared by the co-precipitation method. Na2WO4·2 H2O (9.6 mmol) and CuCl2·2 H2O (9.6 mmol) were dissolved into 60 mL of deionized water under continuous vigorous stirring at room temperature for 3 h. Subsequently, after separating the precipitation from the system by centrifuging, the precipitation was washed with water and ethanol several times. And the precipitation was dried at 90 ℃ for 12 h and calcinated at 400 ℃ for 12 h. And the xRu/CuWO4 (x = 0.05 or 0.2) were prepared by the similar method with different loading of Ru (0.05 or 0.2 wt%). The M/CuWO4 (M= Ru, Pt, and Pd) catalysts were prepared by excessive impregnation method on the CuWO4 precursor with the loading of 0.1 wt%. The aqueous solution of M was impregnated with the CuWO4 precursor followed by drying at 120 ℃ for 12 h and calcinating at 400 ℃ for 2 h. 2.3 Catalytic reaction process The fresh catalysts (0.5 g, 20–40 mesh) were packed into a continuous-flow-fixed-bed reactor (with 9 mm ID) by the quartz wool, which was heated by a muffle furnace to test the glucose hydrogenolysis activity of those catalysts. And the reaction temperature was monitored by a K-type thermocouple controlled by a PID controller. Before the reaction of glucose hydrogenolysis, the fresh catalysts (0.5 g, 20–40 mesh) were in-situ pre-reduced by H2 at 350 ℃ for 10 h at 0.1 MPa with GHSV(H2) = 9600 cm3/(g−1·h−1) in the reactor. After the pre-reduced, the glucose aqueous solution (2.5 wt%) was brought into the reaction system by an infusion pump (LC-20AT, Shimadzu), whose flow rate at 0.05 mL/min (LHSV = 12 cm3 g−1 h−1), and mixed with H2 co-feeding. Liquid products were collected in a gas-liquid separator immersed in a cold trap. The reaction conditions were as follows: 205 ℃, 5.0 MPa H2, (GHSV = 8400 cm3g−1h−1), and 2.5 wt% glucose aqueous solution (LHSV = 12 cm3 g−1 h−1). The effluent gas was analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC-2014 C, Shimadzu) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to analyze the small amount of CH4, C2H6. During the reaction, the liquid product was separated from the reaction system for an hour to observe the trend of the product distribution while the reaction was carried out. And the liquid-phase product was off-line analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Waters 2695) which was equipped with a refractive index detector (RID) (Waters 2414, RI detector) and a Shodex SH-1011 column (7 μm, 8*300 mm). The mobile phase was 5 mM H2SO4 with a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The temperature of the column and detector was 50 ℃. The glucose conversion was calculated on a carbon-mole basis, as follows: (1) Glu. Conv. = {(Gluinlet - Gluoutlet) / Gluinlet} × 100% The selectivity of polyol product was based on the mol selectivity and obtained according to the: (2) S = {NCxHyOz / ∑NCxHyOz} × 100% NCxHyOz indicated the molar number toward a product with x carbon atoms. The carbon balance was calculated as follows: (3) Carbon Balance = {∑(NCxHyOz × x)/NGlu × 6}×100%. NCxHyOz indicated the molar number toward a product with x carbon atoms. NGlu indicated the molar number of the converted glucose. The carbon balance of the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts is above 95%. 2.4 Catalysts characterization To compare the fresh and the reduced samples, the fresh samples were pre-reduced at 350 ℃ for 10 h in H2 flow. After these reduced samples cooled down to room temperature, the samples were passivated with 1 vol% O2/N2 to form a metal oxide layer on the surface, which could prevent complete oxidation when the catalysts were exposed to air, named the passivated catalysts. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of fresh, passivated, and catalysts in the beginning and stable steps were detected by XRD 600 (Shimadzu, Japan) from 5 to 90° with a scanning rate of 5° min−1 equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA. Raman spectra of fresh catalysts and the catalysts in the beginning and stable steps were recorded at room temperature with an inVia Reflex spectrometer (Renishaw) using the 514 nm argon-ion laser. For the characterization of the catalyst morphology, we performed a scanning electron microscope (SEM) on a JSM-6701 F(JEOL) scanning electron microscope operating at 20 kV with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurements were performed on an FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin transmission electron microscope at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV with an energy-dispersive X-ray Spectrometer (EDS). Scanning transmission electron microscopy-high angle annular dark field (STEM-HAADF) analysis was also carried out on the same apparatus as HRTEM. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 was calculated by using Quantachrome autosorb iQ equipment (Quantachrome, USA). The pore properties were analyzed by the Barrett−Joyner−Halenda method. H2-Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analyses were carried out in a quartz tube reactor with a loading of 0.1 g catalysts. And the H2-TPR profiles were collected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) from 90 ℃ to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min in a gas flow of 10% vol H2/Ar after the purging for 30 min. To analyze the valence state and chemical environment of Cu and W species in CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies (XPS) and Aguar electron spectra (AES) of these samples were collected on a Thermo ESCALAB Xl+ spectrometer with the monochromatized Al Kα source. To exclude as much as possible the influence of air on the catalysts in the different reaction steps, the samples were preserved in an N2 atmosphere before they were transferred to the analysis chamber which is also filled with N2. The contaminated carbon C 1 s signal (284.6 eV) was used to calibrate binding energy (B.E.). NH3-Temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were conducted on a Quantachrome autosorb iQ equipment (Quantachrome, USA). For each trial of NH3-TPD, all samples were pre-reduced by 10% vol H2/Ar for 2 hours at reaction temperature (205 ℃). After cooling down to room temperature in a He flow, the samples were exposed to a 5% vol NH3/He flow for saturation adsorption of NH3. Subsequently, in a He flow the NH3-TPD profiles were collected by TCD from room temperature to 600 ℃, with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. In-situ CO-DRIFT spectra were collected on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector at the liquid nitrogen temperature. The pre-reduced catalysts were set in an infrared cell with a ZnSe window and reduced in situ for 1 h in H2 flow at 350 ℃ at atmospheric pressure. Then, the infrared cell was purged by N2 flow for 1 h. After the introduction of carbon monoxide (CO) at RT for 0.5 h and purging by N2 for 1 h, the spectra were collected with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans. The operando EG diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (operando EG-DRIFTS) was collected on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. The pre-reduced sample was placed in an infrared cell with a ZnSe window and reduced in situ for 1 h in H2 flow at 350 ℃ at atmospheric pressure. After that, N2 was introduced into the cell to purge for 0.5 h. Then, EG carried by N2 was brought into the cell for 1 h at 205 ℃. Subsequently, the infrared cell was purged by N2 for 1 h. Then, H2 was introduced into the cell to detect the process of EG hydrogenolysis. All spectra were collected with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans. Pyridine-Fourier Transform Infrared (Py-FTIR) spectroscopy was collected using a FTIR spectrometer (Bruker Tensor 27). The samples were in-situ reduced in H2 flow at 205 ℃ in the reaction cell before the experiments. The background spectrum was recorded at 50 ℃. After the adsorption of pyridine vapor for 0.5 h, the physically adsorbed pyridine was removed under a vacuum and the spectrum was recorded. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic performance in glucose hydrogenolysis Table S1 and Fig. 1 summarize the catalytic performances of different noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalysts in glucose hydrogenolysis. As listed in Table S1, the major products are EtOH, 1,3-PDO, and EG over all catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1A, the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts perform slight deactivation in the initial period and exhibit excellent stability in the steady state within 40 h with a high glucose conversion of 84.3%. However, although the CuWO4 catalyst realizes the highest initial glucose conversion, it continuously deactivates during glucose hydrogenolysis reaction which is the same as the Pt and Pd promoted catalysts. As compared in Table S1 and Fig. 1B, the CuWO4 catalyst shows 57.3% EtOH selectivity, and the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst maintained the highest selectivity of EtOH (63.2%) after 40 hours of reaction. The Ru/CuWO4 catalysts with different Ru loading (0.05 or 0.2 wt%) were also tested in glucose hydrogenolysis reaction, and the reaction performance was exhibited in Fig S2 and Table S2. As these two catalysts showed continuous deactivation, lower glucose conversion and EtOH selectivity compared to the 0.1Ru/CuWO4. Significantly, as listed in Table S3, compared to the reported hydrogenolysis of cellulose or glucose to ethanol, the best yield and STY of EtOH were achieved by the 0.1Ru/CuWO4 catalyst via fixed bed reactor in this work. As the formation of EtOH is dominated by C-O cleavage of EG during hydrogenolysis reaction [4,15], it is believed that the added small amount of Ru is advantageous to form the most active sites for selectively cleaving the C-O bonds of EG on the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts. Interestingly, for the noble metal promoted catalyst, the different noble metals would improve the formation of different products, such as the Pt/CuWO4 catalyst exhibiting the highest selectivity of 1,3-PDO (28.6%) as compared to Table S1 and Fig. S1. It indicates that the added noble metal might tune the surface chemical states of Cu and W species, inducing the formation of different active sites on the surface of various catalysts. On the other hand, as illustrated in Fig. 1, it can be seen that the glucose conversion and EtOH selectivity are dynamically decreasing with time on stream, implying that the surface chemical states of the different catalysts are adjusted during the reaction in the continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Therefore, in order to reveal the active phase over these catalysts, the relationship between reaction performance and structural properties of the obtained catalysts in the initial (the 2nd hour of time on the reaction stream) and steady (the last hour of time on reaction stream) state was characterized by various methods. 3.2 Characterization 3.2.1 Morphology of various catalysts As shown in Fig. S3, all the fresh catalysts exhibit the characteristic peaks of CuWO4 (PDF#70–1732), demonstrating the well-synthesized fresh CuWO4 catalyst. Additionally, there were no diffraction peaks of the added noble metals could be observed, due to the high dispersion and ultralow loading of these noble metals (0.1 wt%). Meanwhile, the N2-adsorption-desorption results of all fresh CuWO4 catalysts (Fig. S4) display the type-II N2 sorption isotherm typically assigned to non-porosity catalysts with very low specific surface area (Table S4), which would avoid the influence of diffusion limitation in the multiphase reaction and is advantageous to investigating the nature role of the active phase on the surface of catalysts [16]. As shown in Fig. 2A, the XRD patterns of the various catalysts in the initial state exhibit the diffraction peaks of metallic Cu, Cu2O species, and WOx species. Notably, metallic Cu species are seen as the active site facilitating the dissociation of H2 for promoting hydrogenation reaction. And Cu+ usually acts as LAS to adsorb and activate carbon-oxygen bonds [13,14,17]. Meanwhile, WOx is known as both LAS and BAS in previous studies [18,19]. And the LASs on the WOx species are recognized as the active sites for selectively cleaving C-C bonds via Retro-aldol condensation (RAC) in glucose conversion [18]. Interestingly, it is complicated that the LASs and BASs over the WOx species mutually transform in H2O and H2 atmosphere dynamically [19]. Compared with the XRD results of various catalysts in the initial state, the XRD patterns of the steady state catalysts (Fig. 2B) show sharper and stronger diffraction peak of WOx species (2θ = 23.4°), indicating that the sintering of crystalline WOx might be the reason for the slight decline in glucose conversion over all catalysts. Meanwhile, the crystalline sizes of metallic Cu on different steady catalysts, calculated by the Scherrer formula and listed in Table S4, suggested the slight sintering of Cu particles during the hydrogenolysis reaction. For analyzing the molecular structures, the Raman spectra of the fresh catalysts were displayed in Fig. S5. The band at 905 cm−1 with strong intensity was attributed to the symmetric stretching of W-O modes for a regular octahedron (WO6), which corresponded to the CuWO4 structure. Meanwhile, the bands at 224, 282, 733, and 778 also revealed the formation of CuWO4, which was in line with the XRD pattern [20,21]. Besides, the Raman spectra of the catalysts in initial and steady states were also collected ( Fig. 3). It is worth noting that in each Raman spectra the bands at ∼708 and 802 cm−1 could be attributed to W-O bending and W-O stretching of the disordered WO6 units, respectively [20]. The symmetric stretching of W-O modes for a regular octahedron (WO6) of CuWO4 structure is located at 902 cm−1 in Fig. 3, due to the lengthening of the W-O bond in CuWO4 catalysts after reduction [21]. Moreover, the band at ∼265 cm−1 should be assigned to the deformation mode of W-O-W. For the Pd/CuWO4 and Pt/CuWO4 catalysts, the samples of steady states display a shoulder peak at 958 cm−1 which should be attributed to terminal νs(WO) of WOx species [22]. Meanwhile, the intensity of bands at 265, 708 and 802 cm−1 obviously decrease for the Pd/CuWO4 and Pt/CuWO4 catalysts in steady states. These evidences suggest the sintering of WOx during the reaction, which would lead to lower glucose conversion over the Pt/CuWO4 and Pd/CuWO4 catalysts [23]. Furthermore, compared to the initial state catalysts, it is found that the Bg vibration mode of CuO at ∼627 cm−1 appears in the Raman spectra of the steady state catalysts [24]. Besides, as shown in Fig. 3B, the intensity of peaks at ∼218 cm−1, attributed to the typical vibration of Cu2O [25], significantly decreases after reaction for all samples. Therefore, it is believed that the decrease of Cu0 species dynamically occurred during the hydrogenolysis reaction, leading to deactivation of all catalysts as illustrated in Fig. 1. From the HR-TEM images of the catalysts in the steady state in Fig. 4, the Cu, Cu2O species and various partially reduced WOx (0<x<3) species could be observed, which is in line with the XRD results. The SEM and EDS results of the catalysts in the steady state (Fig. S6) illustrate the homogeneous distribution of Cu and W elements on the catalysts, which provide a great environment to establish synergistic effects on converting glucose into EtOH and 1,3-PDO. Meanwhile, combined with the XRD, Raman, SEM and HR-TEM images, it can be revealed that during the hydrogenolysis reaction the catalysts contain the various Cu species and partially reduced WOx species, those are considered as the active sites for activating H2, RAC and HDO reaction. The synergistic effects of Cu and WOx species should be the key to the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose to EtOH. 3.2.2 The chemical states of various catalysts The reduction behavior of various catalysts was determined by H2-TPR. As illustrated in the H2-TPR profile ( Fig. 5), the reduction peaks between 100 and 400 ℃ can be attributed to the reduction process of CuO→Cu2O→Cu [26]. It can be seen that CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4 catalysts display a higher Cu species reduction temperature compared with Pt/CuWO4 and Pd/CuWO4, indicating that there is a stronger interaction between Cu and W on CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4 catalysts [27]. Moreover, compared to the CuWO4 catalyst, the added Ru promoter shifts the Cu species reduction peak to a lower temperature, suggesting that the promoted reduction of Cu species. Besides, the reduction peaks of different W species can also be found in Fig. 5. For the CuWO4 catalyst, the broad reduction peak centered at around 603 and 766 ℃, which is assigned with the reduction process of W6+→W5+→W4+ [5,6]. Meanwhile, all the reduction peaks of W species on noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalysts exhibit a shift to the lower temperature, suggesting that the addition of noble metals can effectively promote the reduction of W species [28]. These changes could influence the properties of the acid active sites and hydrogen activation sites, which should lead to different product distribution over the various catalysts. To clarify the surface chemical state of various catalysts, XPS measurement is conducted for different catalysts in various states. Before XPS characterization, the samples were preserved in N2 atmosphere to avoid oxidation in air. For the added noble metals (Ru, Pt, Pd), their signals cannot be detected due to very low loading (0.1 wt%), as shown in Fig. S7. The Cu 2p XPS of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. S8 (A). The distinct peaks at ∼934.9 and ∼955.0 eV are attributed to the Cu2+ 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 [29]. Meanwhile, the peaks located at ∼932.6 and ∼952.4 eV (Fig. S8 (A)) are ascribed as the contribution of Cu0 and Cu+ together due to the Cu0 and Cu+ sharing similar B.E. [17,29], which is generated from the partial reduction of CuWO4. The XPS peaks with weaker intensity at ∼944.2 and 941.8 eV are attributed to the satellite peaks of Cu species [30]. Higher B.E. of Cu species on the CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4 illustrates a stronger interaction between Cu and W species due to the electron transfer from Cu to W [27,31,32], which is in line with H2-TPR result. However, since the B.E. of Cu+ and Cu0 overlap around ∼932.6 eV, the various catalysts exhibit a similar B.E. value. Meanwhile, the intensity of Cu2+ species of the noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalyst is much weaker than that of CuWO4 catalyst due to the promotional effect of noble metal on the reduction, as proved by H2-TPR. With the time on stream of reaction, the intensity of the Cu2+ XPS peaks became obviously stronger from the reduced ones to the initial and steady states as shown in Fig. S8 and Fig. 6. It demonstrated the decrease of Cu0 content during the glucose hydrogenolysis reaction, leading to decline of EtOH selectivity. To clarify the surface Cu species, Cu LMM AES was carried out to distinguish the Cu species with different valance states [17,29]. Fig. S8 (B) displays Cu LMM AES of samples after H2 reduction, where three fitted peaks at 916.3, 915.1 and 918.0 eV are attributed to the Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0, respectively [33–35]. And the kinetic energies of various catalysts are listed in Table S5. Besides, the intensity of Cu2+ species of the noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalyst is much weaker than that of the CuWO4 catalyst as a result of the promotional effect on the reduction by the added noble metal. Additionally, the content of Cu0 and Cu+ is significantly increased as a result of the promoted reducibility as listed in Table S5, which is in line with the result of H2-TPR. Meanwhile, due to the electronic transfer from Cu to W, lower Cu LMM kinetic energies of CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4 catalysts imply a stronger interaction between Cu and W [27,31], as displayed in Cu XPS (Fig. S8(A)). It is considered that stronger interaction between Cu and W and higher content of Cu0 active sites of hydrogen promoted the stability of the catalyst in the reaction process together [36]. The Cu LMM AES of the various catalysts in the initial and steady states are shown in Fig. 7 and the kinetic energies are listed in Table S6. As observed in Cu 2p XPS (Fig. 6), the increase of the content of Cu2+ over all catalysts is also detected in Cu LMM AES. Furthermore, the intensity of Cu+ and Cu0 is decreased during the reaction caused by the oxidation in an aqueous environment, inducing the deactivation of catalysts. Over the CuWO4 catalysts, the content of Cu2+ is increased drastically compared with the noble metal promoted catalysts during the reaction, indicating that the added noble metal effectively maintains the chemical states of Cu species in the reaction process. Compared with the other M/CuWO4 catalysts, Ru/CuWO4 catalysts consistently exhibit lower kinetic energies of Cu species. It is suggested that the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst maintains stronger Cu-W interaction during the reaction [27,31], which inhibits the chemical state transfer of Cu0 and keeps a higher content of Cu0 species on the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst in the hydrothermal environment [36]. Furthermore, the abundant Cu0 hydrogenation active sites would facilitate the rate-determining step, C2 intermediate converting into EtOH [5,13]. Therefore, compared with the others, the highest content of Cu0 should be the key point of converting glucose into EtOH with higher efficiency and better stability for the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst. The XPS of W 4 f of the reduced catalysts were exhibited in Fig. S9. Compared with CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4, Pt/CuWO4 and Pd/CuWO4 catalysts display peaks with the stronger intensity at ∼33.9 eV attributed to W4+ 4 f7/2 [37], demonstrating that the higher content of W4+ could be formed on Pt/CuWO4 and Pd/CuWO4 catalysts due to the promoted reduction process. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 8, the distinct spin-orbit doublet peaks at ∼35.6 and ∼37.7 eV are ascribed as W5+ 4 f7/2 and W5+4 f5/2, respectively [5,38]. And the peaks of W6+ 4 f7/2 and W6+ 4 f5/2 are located at ∼36.1 and ∼38.2 eV [37]. With noble metal promoters added, W electron density is changed in different ways during the reaction. For Pt/CuWO4 and Pd/CuWO4, the lower B.E. of W was obtained indicating the higher W electron density. It is found that H2 and H2O atmosphere can induce the WOx species to form BAS and increasing the W electron density [19]. However, the higher B.E. of W specie is exhibited on Ru/CuWO4, demonstrating that the added Ru promoter inhibits the BASs formation compared with the Pt/CuWO4 catalyst. Moreover, with the time on stream of the reaction, XPS peaks of W shift to lower B.E. It is suggested that the BASs are further generated due to the electronic transfer from H atom, which is the reason for the increased 1,3-PDO selectivity [39,40]. Among various catalysts, Ru/CuWO4 still shows the highest B.E. of W, illustrating that fewer BASs can be formed. It could be the reason for the highest EtOH selectivity over the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts. In addition, the content of different W species on various catalysts in initial and steady states are listed in Table S7. For the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts, the highest W5+ content indicates that the oxidation of W5+ to W6+ species is restrained during the reaction as compared in Fig. 8A and B. This might be the result of more active hydrogen generated on more Cu0 active sites as proved by Cu LMM AES. Furthermore, the W5+ species were known as LAS for promoting the RAC reaction to cleave C-C selectively for generating C2 intermediate [41], contributing to the higher EtOH selectivity. Therefore, the higher Cu0 content and more W5+ species on Ru/CuWO4 would promote the RAC of glucose during the hydrogenolysis reaction, contributing to the higher EtOH selectivity. However, the BAS formed from the W6+ species could accelerate the formation of 1,3-PDO in glycerol hydrogenolysis [9]. Therefore, for the Pt/CuWO4 catalysts, the addition of Pt contributes the highest content of W6+ with lower B.E., resulting in more BASs, promoting converting C3 intermediates to 1,3-PDO via HDO reaction. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (in-situ DRIFTS) is also applied to probe the Cu species on the surface of various catalysts by CO adsorption. The in-situ CO-DRIFTS of various catalysts are shown in Fig. 9. The vibration frequency of the Ru-CO, Pt-CO, and Pd-CO appears at 2062, 2039, and 2079 cm−1, respectively [42,43]. According to peak fitting of the CuWO4 sample, bands at 2167, 2125 and 2107 cm−1 can be assigned to linear stretching of Cu2+-CO, Cu+-CO, and Cu0-CO species, respectively [44,45]. Meanwhile, CO adsorbed on the W species shows at 2184 cm−1 [46]. In the case of the present results, the chemical states of Cu for the various catalysts are magnified. Compared with the CuWO4 sample, a red shift of CO linear adsorption is observed on the Pt/CuWO4 catalysts. It is indicated that the electron back-donation from the d metallic orbitals to the π* anti-bonding molecular orbital of CO is enhanced [47], implying the higher Cu electron density due to the weaker interaction between Cu and W [27,31]. This is in accordance with the result of XPS. It can be known as the reason for the deactivation of Pt/CuWO4 catalyst. According to the CO-DRIFTS fitting results (Table S8), it can be seen that the ratio of different CO linear adsorption is highly dependent on the content of various Cu species from the result of XPS. Based on the content of the linearly adsorbed CO as compared in Table S8, the Cu0 content of various catalysts decreases in an order of Ru/CuWO4 > Pd/CuWO4 > Pt/CuWO4 > CuWO4. Therefore, it is believed that the highest Cu0 content on the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts contributes to the highest EtOH selectivity in glucose hydrogenolysis as compared in Table S1. 3.2.3 Acid properties of CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts As shown in Fig. 10, the comparison of surface acidic properties of various catalysts in the initial and steady states were detected via ammonia temperature-programmed desorption characterization (NH3-TPD). All samples displayed a wide range of desorption, demonstrating various acid sites are generated for effectively converting glucose. As shown in Fig. 10(A), the desorption peak centered at 100–150 ℃ can be attributed to the weak acid sites of Cu species [48]. Additionally, the medium acid sites on various catalysts are also observed. The larger desorption peak of the medium acid sites on the Ru/CuWO4 at 363 ℃ is indicative of the medium acid site for catalyzing the RAC reaction of glucose [5,11], which would increase the EtOH selectivity during glucose hydrogenolysis. On the other hand, Zhou et al. [9]. believed that the stronger acids, which showed an NH3-TPD peak at about 450 ℃ can be considered as the BASs derived from the WOx species, which was considered as the active sites for the glycerol selectively HDO into 1,3-PDO. Therefore, it is considered that the higher intensity of the strong acid of the Pt/CuWO4 catalysts would promote the 1,3-PDO formation. Compared with the initial catalysts, the desorption peaks shift to lower temperature with the time on stream of the reaction as shown in Fig. 10 (B) due to the deactivation of catalysts. Furthermore, the content of the strong acid site increases with the time on stream of the reaction for all the steady catalysts, indicating that the acid sites with medium acidity convert into strong acid sites, leading to more 1,3-PDO generated as shown in Fig. S1. However, the higher content of medium acid sites is preserved on Ru/CuWO4 with less negative moving compared with the other catalysts, demonstrating that the added Ru promoter is advantageous to converting glucose into EtOH steadily and efficiently. FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-FTIR) were employed to analyze Lewis and Brønsted acid on the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 11. Pyridine coordinates to LASs or protonates on BASs, which displays as a band of 1445/1574/1606 and 1541 cm−1, respectively [49]. The band assigned to the combination of pyridine on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites can be located at 1491 cm−1 [50]. The areas under the infrared bands at 1541 and 1445 cm−1 were selected to calculate the B/L ratios as summarized in Table S9. As shown in Fig. 11, the LASs are dominant on the surface of various catalysts in the initial and steady states attributed to Cu+ and W5+, as proved in XPS results. Importantly, W5+ species were proved as the active site for the RAC reaction to cleave C-C selectively towards the C2 intermediate in glucose hydrogenolysis [5]. And Cu+ species were known as LASs for adsorbing and activating C-O bonds to facilitate HDO reaction with assistance from Cu0 [44,51]. Especially, Ru/CuWO4 catalyst exhibits the highest content of LASs among various catalysts as listed in Table S9. Besides, as proved by Fig. 11 (C), the minimal change in B/L of Ru/CuWO4 with the time on stream of the reaction indicates that the added Ru promoter maintains surface chemical state stability for glucose hydrogenolysis to EtOH. Hence, it is believed that the synergistic effects between abundant LASs and Cu0 species generated on the Ru/CuWO4 surface in the present work would contribute to the formation of EtOH during glucose hydrogenolysis. The dynamic transformation of surface acid properties with the time on stream of the reaction is shown in Table S9. The samples in the steady states display a higher BASs ratio compared with the sample in the initial states, which is in good accordance with the content of W6+ analyzed by XPS (Fig. 6). With the ratio of BASs increasing, EtOH selectivity decreases with the increased 1,3-PDO selectivity over all catalysts, especially the Pt/CuWO4 catalysts. The catalytic performance of the CuWO4 and Ru/CuWO4 catalysts was monitored by operando EG-DRIFTS measurements ( Fig. 12). The EG vapor was introduced into the in-situ cell at 205 ℃ for 1 h with N2 flow, followed by purging by N2 flow for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed EG. After purging by N2, H2 was introduced into the cell and the spectra were collected every 15 min. As illustrated in Fig. 12(A), after EG adsorbing on the CuWO4 catalyst, the bands centered at 1571 cm−1 with a shoulder peak at 1609 cm−1 could be observed. It is reported that the band at 1571 cm−1 is attributed to the υ(OCO) of the adsorbed glycolate, and the band at 1318 cm−1 is also corresponding to the adsorbed glycolate [52–54]. Besides, the band located at 1609 cm−1 is assigned to υ(CO) of the adsorbed glycolaldehyde, and the band at 1393 cm−1 is assigned to δ(CH2) [52]. Meanwhile, the bands located around 1000–1100 cm−1 are attributed to the characteristic C-O bands of alcohol, where bands at ∼1020 cm−1 can be the bidentate-υ(C-O), and the bands at ∼1068 cm−1 should be recognized as the monodentate-υ(C-O) [55,56]. After the purging by N2, H2 was brought into the reaction cell, and the band at 1571 cm−1 displays a blue shift to 1609 cm−1 with the declining intensity of the band at 1318 cm−1, suggesting that H2 converts glycolate into glycolaldehyde. Contemporary, it can be noticed that the intensity of the band of bidentate-υ(C-O) decreases sharply, suggesting the bidentate-υ(C-O) was consumed with the adsorbed EG reacting with H2. Meanwhile, the blue shift from 1020 to 1027 cm−1 for the CuWO4 catalyst indicates that the C-O bonds of EG cleave due to the active H species formed with the formation of EtOH [57,58]. On the other hand, the intensity of bands of δs(CH3) and δas(CH3), located at 1439 and 1351 cm−1 [55,56], significantly increases with time on stream, suggesting the formation of the -CH3 group of EtOH with the H2 introduction. Obviously, in Fig. 12 (B), the higher efficiency is observed on the Ru/CuWO4, proving that the higher content of Cu0 and the added Ru promoter leads to higher hydrogenation activity. It can be noticed that the intensity of these features increases in 60 min after H2 introduced (Fig. 12 (B), Line e) for the Ru/CuWO4. However, for the CuWO4, the obvious increase of the features of -CH3 group in 90 min after H2 brought into the cell (Fig. 12 (A), Line g), suggesting that the EG hydrogenolysis reaction displays a higher reaction rate over Ru/CuWO4 than that over CuWO4. As previously reported [15], converting EG into EtOH was considered the rate-determining step of the hydrogenolysis of glucose into EtOH. The higher reaction rate of converting EG to EtOH over the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst could be the reason for the highest EtOH selectivity during the glucose hydrogenolysis. Therefore, the added Ru promoter effectively contributes to creating more acid sites (W5+ species) and hydrogenation active sites (Cu0 species) on the catalyst surface, leading to accelerated C2 intermediate formation and conversion, resulting in higher ethanol selectivity. Consequently, it is reasonable to believe that the Cu0 and W5+ species significantly affect EtOH selectively. As illustrated in Fig. 13, the EtOH selectivity of the CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts is correlated with the content of Cu0 and W5+ species. The content of the Cu0 species is in an order of Ru/CuWO4 > Pd/CuWO4 > Pt/CuWO4 > CuWO4, based on the XPS (Fig. 13 (A)) and in situ CO-DRIFT (Fig. 13. (B)) data. And the content of W5+ decreases as the order of Ru/CuWO4 > Pd/CuWO4 > CuWO4 > Pt/CuWO4. Therefore, the relative content of Cu0 and W5+ can be considered as the reason for the different EtOH selectivity over the various CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts. Additionally, the introduction of Ru makes an essential effect on tuning the chemical states of Cu and W to form the highest content of Cu0 and W5+, leading to the higher EtOH selectivity in glucose hydrogenolysis reaction over the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts. Besides, it is generally known that the isomerization between glucose and fructose can occur on Lewis acid active sites [59]. And the following retro-aldol condensation (RAC) reaction on fructose leads to the C-C bonds between C3 and C4 selective cleavage and forms glyceraldehyde and hydroxyacetone as C3 intermediates which can be converted into glycerol via hydrogenation. As reported in the previous studies [60], 1,3-PDO can be generated over the BASs in the glycerol HDO reaction by selectively cleaving the secondary C-OH of the glycerol intermediate. Furthermore, the 1,3-PDO selectivity of various catalysts is correlated with the content of the BASs, which increased in an order of Ru/CuWO4 < Pd/CuWO4 < CuWO4 < Pt/CuWO4. Meanwhile, the content of the W6+ of the various catalysts, detected by XPS and shown in Table S7, increased in the same order as the content of the BASs. Simultaneously, the 1,3-PDO selectivity over the various catalysts is followed in the same order, indicating that W6+ could be employed as the BASs for the selective hydrogenolysis of glucose into 1,3-PDO. 4 Conclusion Selective hydrogenolysis of glucose into EtOH was investigated over CuWO4 and M/CuWO4 catalysts using a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Combined with the results of the various characterizations, it is found that the introduction of the noble metal promotors tunes the surface chemical states of Cu and W species, as well as the acid groups, which are essential for adjusting the selectivity of the specific product. Among the catalysts, the Ru/CuWO4 catalysts with the highest content of Cu0 and W5+ performed the highest EtOH selectivity with excellent stability, due to the synergistic effects of the Cu0 and W5+, which effectively promoted EG hydrogenation to EtOH. On the other hand, the strong BASs derived from W6+ are advantageous to forming 1,3-PDO on Pt/CuWO4 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Biomass is the most promising carbon feedstock for producing chemicals and fuels as substitutes for fossil resources. In this work, hydrogenolysis of glucose to ethanol (EtOH) and 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) were carried out over multi-function noble metal promoted CuWO4 (0.1 wt% Ru, Pt and Pd) catalysts using a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor. Amazingly, the Ru/CuWO4 catalyst presented the best catalytic performance with 84.3% glucose conversion, 63.2% EtOH and 21.2% 1,3-PDO selectivities over 40 h reaction. An array of characterization techniques, including XPS, Cu LMM AES, in-situ CO-DRIFTS, NH3-TPD, Py-FTIR, and operando EG-DRIFTS, were applied to reveal the nature of converting glucose into EtOH and 1,3-PDO. It is discovered that the added small amount of Ru tuned the chemical states of W and Cu, resulting in forming the highest content of W5+ and Cu0 on the Ru-promoted catalyst, which improves the glucose hydrogenolysis to EtOH. Besides, the strong Brønsted acid sites (BASs) derived from W6+ contribute to relatively high 1,3-PDO selectivity on Pt/CuWO4 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient synthesis of ethanol and propanediol from glucose via a noble metal promoted CuWO4 catalyst
